posts.author: mastersuntzu
posts.content:
I was looking for some help creating a Druid/Shifter/Paladin
Base Criteria that must be met: 5 levels of Druid & Shifter - 10 levels of Paladin

1. PvP or PvM - Prefer something that can hold its own in PvP
2. Capped at level 20
3. Human
4. I prefer to play board & sword type of characters, and the change in my current build is based upon lore in the PW that I currently play in.
5. I would like to be able to stay board & sword and have the ability to shift when its necessary or makes RP sense for my character.
6. Range preference is not important.
7. Weapon preference is longsword.
8. Enchantment levels: +5 max
9. Magic use: I am figuring on being buff reliant and a party buffer.
10. Custom Factors: Must have 5 levels in druid & shifter and 10 levels in Paladin.

Any help would greatly be appreciated. Thank you in advance.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
mastersuntzu wrote:I was looking for some help creating a Druid/Shifter/Paladin
A very interesting combination for RP! But it is hard to find good synergies for pre- epic powerbuilding.
Base Criteria that must be met: 5 levels of Druid & Shifter - 10 levels of Paladin
That's a pity because Paladin 4/Druid 8/Shifter 8 is a much stronger build with with greater RP potential. It has the same BAB, better saves, lvl 4 spells and humanoid shape!

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content: Not to mention you will need an alignment shift to be a pally druid. How exactly are you planning to do that?

posts.author: mastersuntzu
posts.content:
There are RP avenues to allow me to go through changes, it would take a long time to accomplish, but achievable. I agree that the pre-epic synergies are difficult at best. I have been toying with the build and its just not working. The reason I have to have 5 levels is because of a Prestige Class requirement on the PW. A minimum of 5 levels in each class must be taken, so I suppose that the paladin levels could be reduced, but then I lose a lot of that classes abilities as well.

I do appreciate the help.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Honestly, capping at lvl 20 I would consider not going for a 3 class build. How about a Druid 12 Shifter 8? I Don't know if I understood you correctly, so let me check:

If you want to have a Prestige Class, you need to have at least 5 levels on ALL CLASSES? Like in the case you said you wanted: Pal at least 5, Druid at least 5 and Shifter at least 5? Cuz if that's so then you only have 5 other levels to distribute among one or more than one of these classes to reach 20.

Have you ever thought of a simpler but much more effective Druid 16 Monk 4? Shifting only to animals and later on Elementals?

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
mastersuntzu wrote:A minimum of 5 levels in each class must be taken, so I suppose that the paladin levels could be reduced
In that case I would take Paladin 5/Druid 8/Shifter 7. It will not be quite as good as the 4/8/8 split because of lower saves, but you will still get much from shifter and have lvl 4 spells from druid.
but then I lose a lot of that classes abilities as well.
Paladin doesn't get much between level 5 and level 10, only a lvl 1 and a lvl 2 spellslot.

From the perspective of a powerbuilder, it is better to avoid too many classes pre epic, just like Max said.
Druid benefits from better shapes and powerful high lvl spells with increasing levels. Shifters get their better forms with increasing levels. Paladin is quite "frontloaded" with most feats from the first 3 levels.

posts.author: mastersuntzu
posts.content:
Maximillian Kane wrote:Honestly, capping at lvl 20 I would consider not going for a 3 class build. How about a Druid 12 Shifter 8? I Don't know if I understood you correctly, so let me check:
Yes, I have other characters that I have multiclassed, but in this case the Paladin addition is for a specific RP.
Maximillian Kane wrote:If you want to have a Prestige Class, you need to have at least 5 levels on ALL CLASSES? Like in the case you said you wanted: Pal at least 5, Druid at least 5 and Shifter at least 5? Cuz if that's so then you only have 5 other levels to distribute among one or more than one of these classes to reach 20.

Yes, in order to have a Prestige Class in your build you must have a minimum of 5 levels in each class you select. So if I wanted a build that had RDD in it, I would need to take something like RDD 10/Ftr 5/Bard 5 or Paladin 15/CoT 5. As long as there is a minimum of 5 levels in each class.
Maximillian Kane wrote:Have you ever thought of a simpler but much more effective Druid 16 Monk 4? Shifting only to animals and later on Elementals?
I actually have played that build before and its quite effective, but as I said above, its specifically for an RP avenue.
Take it EZ!
I appreciate your help. Thank you.
Mick Dagger wrote:In that case I would take Paladin 5/Druid 8/Shifter 7. It will not be quite as good as the 4/8/8 split because of lower saves, but you will still get much from shifter and have lvl 4 spells from druid.
I was thinking of the same thing, How would you distribute the levels in order to get the best AB?

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content: The AB is defined by the classes, not the order in which you get the classes, so it doesn't really matter

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: How about Ranger instead of Druid and Shifter? That would remove the alignment conflict, and you could still RP protecting nature.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
mastersuntzu wrote:Druid(5), Shifter(5), Paladin(10), Human

STR: 10
DEX: 10
CON: 12
WIS: 17 (22)
INT: 14
CHA: 11
Epic druid and shifter builds focus on wisdom to be able to qualify for epic feats/shapes. The only thing you will get from a high wisdom here is a couple of bonus spellslots, a better will save and a stat bonus to the spot skill, a skill you don't need the moment you have the wyrmling shapes with their TS. The shapes you get will override strength, dexterity and constitution to some extent, but you want to go sword and board and not depend upon your shapes, so you will need a good strength and a fair amount of constitution. You may even want some dexterity since you don't have the cat's grace spell.
Cha 11 gives you nothing unless you improve it with items or eagle's splendor.
My suggestion is:
Str 15 (20)
Dex 12
Con 14
Wis 14
Int 12
Cha10
Taking Int 12 instead of 14 gives 1 less skill, maybe you can do without concentration
Human: (Quick to Master)
01: Paladin(1): Alertness, Weapon Focus: Longsword
03: Paladin(3): Blind Fight
06: Paladin(6): Extend Spell
09: Paladin(9): Improved Critical: Longsword
12: Druid(3): Spell Focus: Conjuration
15: Shifter(1): Spell Penetration
18: Shifter(4): Greater Spell Focus: Conjuration
Why all those meta magic feats? Paladin has 10 caster levels, level 2 spells and no attack spells. Druid has 5 caster levels and level 3 spells and will not be a very effective spellslinger even with such feats. Why focus in conjuration when the only conjuration attack spell is grease, while there are several evocation and necromancy attack spells and even transmutation attack spells. There are several combat feats that will serve you better.
Extend can be of some use for buffing and can make the druid spells last equally long as the paladin spells.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content: Good suggestions Mick, spot on!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I usually take PA and Cleave early to benefit from the extra attack when the character has few attacks per round. The extra attack is ok later as well, but IMO best early on.
I am not a big fan of Great Cleave. It looks good on paper almost promising a chain reaction of kills. But in practical play that doesn't happen very often because it stops the moment your hit doesn't kill. Most hits don't kill unless you fight very weak creatures. I would rather take Knockdown.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
An extremely nerfed combo split which is typical of RP builds so no need to fret that issue. You should notice that this build is similar to the last one posted.

I am assuming either an available alignment manager on the server or a DM to support this function. You never
explained how this was to be handled when Max asked (unless I missed it). Druid and pally are the 2 most strict
classes to deal with, hence the paucity of any similar combos being documented in the ECB knowledge base.
Otherwise, you will find these switches all but impossible to enact since chaos axis changes are seldom scripted
(at least not on those I've played). Nonetheless...

The 10-5-5 split appears to be cast in concrete according to the previous description of the RP prereqs so the
displayed build reflects that. However, if you are unfamiliar with playing shifter, let me explain that in
order to optimize combat potential, it is normally best to decide EXACTLY which forms will be your primary
ones and support those choices. It is impossible to excel in all forms, though each of them have their uses,
situationally, that is.

I have decided in this build that in order to maintain as high a primary class (ala Paladin) potential as possible,
the minotaur form would suit best. That form gets full merge (weapon, armor, items) so the battleaxe seems
a no-brainer. The shifter version automatically gets +1 enhancement so Bless Weapon is not needed shifted.
Longsword focus would work with humanoid wildshape, but that is not available until Shf 7.
In addition to fighting as minotaur, I recommend getting familiar with using the wyrmling breath weapons,
so Expertise was chosen to augment AC a bit in those cases.

One thing to keep in mind is that minotaur shape is less likely to be KD'd than pally and cannot be disarmed.

Another option is to go spear-focused for drider with the +2 onhit poison spear but that is a 2h weapon and the pally
will lose AC equipped that way.

Abilities

STR will get overwritten by both minotaur and wyrmling but that doesn't mean a prebuff of Bull's Str won't be just as useful as in pally form. DEX does NOT get overwritten by minotaur so the additional DEX AC is useful as well as a slight boost (-1 to 0) to the poor reflex saves. I would be wary of traps because most of them are reflex DCs. CON also gets overwritten by most of the wyrmlings but was set to 12 as an alternative to Toughness in a feat-starved build like this.

Another spread worth considering is 18(23), 8, 12, 14, 12, 8... perhaps a stronger spread, though limiting the wyrmling shape.

Do NOT be intimated by ODD final ability levels for 2 reasons: 1) maximum item enhancement on the server may
favor an odd number (EVEN ability levels assume the +12 cap can normally be reached by all players), and 2) buffs
are a d4 dice roll so half the time (theoretically) the odd number is beneficial over the even one.

I would discourage any "waste" of spell focus feats since both the WIS and caster levels are so low that DCs will be
rather easy to beat with or without the feats factored in. It's a matter of poor return on your investment, IMHO.
Use the same reasoning with Spell Pen feats. Just too few caster levels to make it feasible and feats should be
better utilized. I am assuming there are no RP constraints regarding feat selection, naturally.

Bottom line on the entire discussion: Decide how much you want to play the shifter (and/or druid) shapes, decide on a primary and secondary shape focus and then begin planning your build. Any other approach will be similar to throwing a dart at a board blind-folded (even with Blind Fight ).

Paladin(10), Druid(5), Shifter(5), Human

STR: 17 (22)
DEX: 10
CON: 12
WIS: 14
INT: 13
CHA: 8

01: Pal-1 WF: Battleaxe, Blind Fight
02: Pal-2
03: Pal-3 Power Attack
04: Pal-4 STR+1 (18)
05: Pal-5
06: Pal-6 Cleave
07: Pal-7
08: Pal-8 STR+1 (19)
09: Pal-9 Alertness
10: Dru-1 *Alignment Change*
11: Dru-2
12: Dru-3 STR+1 (20), Extend Spell
13: Dru-4
14: Dru-5
15: Shf-1 Imp Crit: Battleaxe
16: Shf-2 STR+1 (21)
17: Shf-3
18: Shf-4 Expertise (See Note for Options)
19: Shf-5
20: Pal-10 STR+1 (22), *Alignment Change*

HP: 200
Saves(F/WR) 16/9/9 (19/12/12 vs. spells)
Save bonuses: Fear: +2
BAB: 16
AB (max, naked) 23 (melee), 17 (ranged)
AC (naked/mundane armor/shield only) 13/24
Spell Casting: Pal(2),Dru(3)

Skills
Animal Empathy 22(21), Discipline 23(29), Heal 11(12), Listen 22(25), Spellcraft 14(15), Tumble 10(11)

Note:

Other suitable feats at Lvl 18 might be KD (for pally) or Imp Crit: Unarmed (for greater support of miscellaneous shifter and druid forms).

Edit: Fixed ability spread. Doh!
